rollover.translation[0].definitions[0].d: when money is moved from one bank account or investment to another without any tax or other fees having to be paid
rollover.translation[0].definitions[0].e: Many CD rollovers happen in October.
rollover.translation[0].definitions[1].d: the action of making a bank account, investment etc do this
rollover.translation[0].definitions[1].e: The law allows a rollover of retirement money from a company pension to an IRA.
rollover.translation[0].definitions[2].d: if there is a rollover in a competition or lottery, nobody wins the biggest prize that week, and the money is added to the prize that can be won the following week
rollover.translation[0].definitions[3].d: an accident in which a car turns over onto its roof
rollover.translation[0].definitions[4].d: a way of making the images change whenever someone using a MOUSE moves it over a particular word or picture on a computer screen
rollover.translation[1].definitions[0].d: an occasion when an investment is moved from one financial institution to another without being taxed
rollover.translation[1].definitions[0].e: a direct rollover of retirement funds from your former employer to a new pension
rollover.translation[1].definitions[1].d: when a loan etc that ends in one period of time is replaced by a similar loan etc in the following period
rollover.translation[1].definitions[1].e: continued rollover of maturing commercial paper
rollover.translation[1].definitions[2].d: an occasion when a company changes the products that it sells
rollover.translation[1].definitions[2].e: The new series of machines comes just 10 months after the last rollover of the product line.
rollover.translation[1].definitions[3].d: a way of making an image change or appear whenever someone uses the MOUSE to move the CURSOR over a particular word or picture on a computer screen
